Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nRIYADH: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered that the border with Qatar be reopened to allow pilgrims to carry out their annual haj pilgrimage to Mecca, official state media said Thursday.\n\nThe decision represents the first step forward since a diplomatic crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5.\n\nThe border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to a statement from the Saudi News Agency.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage,\" it said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nQatari authorities last month accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to Iran.\n\nQatar denies the charges and has accused its Gulf neighbours of seeking to strangle its economy.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80% of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily {"id": "9596752", "categories": [{"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710636014", "source": {"id": "2530", "title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/world/gulf-diplomatic-crisis-saudi-arabia-to-reopen-border-with-qatar-to-allow-hajj-3939141.html", "body": "Riyadh: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered that the border with Qatar be reopened to allow pilgrims to carry out their annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, official state media said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision represents the first step forward since a diplomatic crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on 5 June.\n\nFile image of King of Saudi Arabia Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud. AP\n\nThe border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to a statement from the Saudi News Agency.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage,\" it said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nQatari authorities last month accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to Iran.\n\nQatar denies the charges and has accused its Gulf neighbours of seeking to strangle its economy.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 17, 2017 {"id": "9603559", "categories": [{"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710657838", "source": {"id": "147", "title": "enca.com", "uri": "enca.com"}, "url": "http://www.enca.com/world/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims", "body": "RIYADH - Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasized the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardizing the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. The pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims who can perform it at least once in their lives", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:25:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 409, King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a {"id": "9625631", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710717890", "source": {"id": "468", "title": "The Nation", "uri": "nation.com.pk"}, "url": "http://nation.com.pk/international/17-Aug-2017/qatar-border-open-to-pilgrims-on-saudi-king-s-order", "body": "RIYADH: Saudi Arabia s King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region s worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia s powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year s hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world s richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year s hajj. The pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims who can must perform it at least once in their lives.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T06:39:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 423, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to {"id": "9616717", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 542, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Dogs", "uri": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710694316", "source": {"id": "3799", "title": "geo.tv", "uri": "geo.tv"}, "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/154010-saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-hajj-pilgrims", "body": "RIYADH: Saudi Arabia\u00b4s King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region\u00b4s worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia\u00b4s powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year\u00b4s hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims\u00b4 safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world\u00b4s richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year\u00b4s hajj. in the region's diplomatic crisis\n\nSaudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the land border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, according to state media, in the first signs of a thaw in the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after Saudi Arabia,along with Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on 5 June, accusing the emirate of supporting Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, received an envoy from Doha, according to the Saudi Press Agency, in the first high-level public encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince had emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatar's Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement said.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned on Thursday that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the border decision. \"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari government,\" tweeted Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based thinktank Arabia Foundation.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting terrorists and of being too close to their regional nemesis, Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate, with a population of 2.6 million, 80% of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest per capita, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds $330bn in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj takes place at the beginning of September this year.\n\nMore than 1.8 million took part in last "https://www.nst.com.my/node/268677", "body": "RIYADH: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered that the border with Qatar be reopened to allow pilgrims to carry out their annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, official state media said Thursday.\n\nThe decision represents the first step forward since a diplomatic crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5.\n\nThe border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to a statement from the Saudi News Agency.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage,\" it said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nQatari authorities last month accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their "710615257", "source": {"id": "661", "title": "themalaymailonline.com", "uri": "themalaymailonline.com"}, "url": "http://www.themalaymailonline.com/world/article/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims", "body": "Muslim pilgrims pray at the Grand mosque in the holy city of Mecca, ahead of the annual haj pilgrimage October 10, 2013. -- Reuters picRIYADH, Aug 17 -- Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said today, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 per cent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj.\n\nThe pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims who can must perform it at least once in their lives. -- AFP", "dateTime": {"id": "9605750", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710663955", "source": {"id": "2273", "title": "The Asian Age", "uri": "asianage.com"}, "url": "http://www.asianage.com/world/middle-east/170817/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims-amid-gulf-crisis.html", "body": "Riyadh: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. The pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims who can must perform it at least once in their lives.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:49:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 423, erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a "2017-08-17", "uri": "710726006", "source": {"id": "308", "title": "News.com.au", "uri": "news.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.news.com.au/finance/economy/world-economy/could-the-qatar-crisis-finally-be-over/news-story/65f0f448e768d176e22f24c72356be0a", "body": "SAUDI Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe Arab nations issued a 13-point list of demands to end the standoff on June 22 and gave the natural gas-rich country 10 days to comply.\n\nThey also ordered Qatari citizens to leave their territories and took various steps against Qatari firms and financial institutions.\n\nBut Qatar's defence minister claimed the \"country is ready to defend itself if necessary\".\n\n\"Qatar is not an easy country to be swallowed by anyone. We are ready. We stand ready to defend our country,\" Khalid Al Attiyah told reporters in July.\n\n\"I hope that we don't come to a stage where, you know, a military intervention is made.\"\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 per cent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. "http://cdn.newsapi.com.au/image/v1/a1488af4f1764ee4e5d25a98de1bd7d9", "timeCrawl": "07:01:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Could the Qatar crisis finally be over?", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9751551", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711042439", "source": {"id": "4037", "title": "Kuwait Times", "uri": "news.kuwaittimes.net"}, "url": "http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/saudis-reopen-border-for-qatar-hajj-pilgrims/", "body": "RIYADH: Qatari hajj pilgrims began to enter Saudi Arabia yesterday, Saudi media reported, as Riyadh reopened the border in a move cautiously welcomed by Doha despite a diplomatic row engulfing the region. The Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage, has been closed since June in a major crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicizing the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Makkah, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia. Around 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory yesterday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits. He also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\", state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicization of religious freedoms. \"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm. \"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicization.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\n'Right to pilgrimage'\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has emerged as the worst political crisis to grip the region in decades. The kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago. The Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government. The decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar. Sheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard. He said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership\". Sheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nCautious\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement yesterday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear\", particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims. The statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nAnalysts cautioned yesterday that the dispute was far from over. \"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically. \"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter. Some Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety. \"I think it is very risky to go to Makkah this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima Al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, Qatar ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund. - Agencies", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T18:16:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 1891, "textStart": 1885, "date": "-06-05", "amb": false}], "uri": "710697397", "source": {"id": "1853", "title": "Dawn", "uri": "dawn.com"}, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1352108", "body": "Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual Haj pilgrimage, state media said on Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform Haj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for Haj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi Arabian Airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nLast month, Saudi Arabia had said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's Haj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising Haj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 per cent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary {"id": "9682870", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710867553", "source": {"id": "7528", "title": "The Sudanese Media Centre", "uri": "smc.sd"}, "url": "http://smc.sd/en/qatar-welcomes-saudi-decision-open-border/", "body": "(agencies) Aug. 17, 2017 Agence France Presse\n\nRIYADH/STOCKHOLM: The Qatari foreign minister on Thursday welcomed Saudi Arabia's decision to reopen the two countries' border to Muslim pilgrims, while lashing out at Riyadh's \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which Qataris were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politicised, and the manner in which they were again permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicised ... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a media conference in Stockholm.\n\nEarlier in the day Saudi Arabia's King Salman ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits,\" a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses.\"\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing hajj and jeopardizing the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. The pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and all Muslims who can must perform it at least once in their lives.\n\nsource:(www.dailystar.com.lb)", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:13:00Z", {"id": "9704061", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710920356", "source": {"id": "380", "title": "The Times of Israel", "uri": "timesofisrael.com"}, "url": "http://www.timesofisrael.com/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims/", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -- Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to hajj pilgrims, state media said Thursday, despite a major diplomatic crisis roiling the region.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing has been closed since June 5 when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar over accusations the emirate fostered Islamist extremists. Qatar has denied the allegation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the frontier for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nKing Salman has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits,\" a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia's King Salman attends a banquet hosted by Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo, March 13, 2017. (Tomohiro Ohsumi/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nThe decision also came after Prince Mohammed received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister welcomed Saudi Arabia's decision but also lashed out at Riyadh's \"politicization\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which Qataris were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politicized, and the manner in which they were again permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicized... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qatari pilgrims would be allowed to enter the kingdom for hajj this year but imposed clear restrictions, including flying via airlines approved by Riyadh.\n\nDoha has accused Riyadh of politicizing the hajj and jeopardizing the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of Qatari citizens.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place at the beginning of September. The pilgrimage is expected to draw around two million people this year.\n\nPrince Mohammed emphasized the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with the Qatari envoy, Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, SPA said.\n\nBut some observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over, despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\nIn this May 14, 2012 file photo, Prince Mohammed bin Salman waits for Gulf Arab leaders ahead of the opening of Gulf Cooperation Council summit, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. (AP/Hassan Ammar, File)\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Commission welcomed the decision, while adding that \"the issue of hajj cannot be subject to any political or personal calculations.\"\n\nThe decision drew strong opinions on social media, with Qataris appearing to respond largely critically.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"He (King Salman) didn't invite them to his own house. And every Muslim has the right to go to hajj,\" wrote another Twitter user.\n\nQatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim Bin Hamad Al-Thani in Riyadh on May 21, 2017. (AFP/Mandel Ngan)\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies have shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional rival Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy Gulf state to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:02:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 256, "textStart": 250, "date": "-06-05", "amb": false}, (AP Photo/Nariman El-Mofty) If I cannot stop namaz on road, I have no right to stop Janmashtami at thana, says UP CM Yogi AdityanathAmit Shah resigns as MLA, says Congress will be reduced to half in next pollsToilet: Ek Prem Katha box office collection day 6: Akshay Kumar film inching towards Rs 100 crore\n\nSaudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered that the border with Qatar be reopened to allow pilgrims to carry out their annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, official state media said today. The decision represents the first step forward since a diplomatic crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5.\n\nThe border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to a statement from the Saudi News Agency. The king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage,\" it said. He even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nQatari authorities last month accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety. Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to Iran.\n\nQatar denies the charges and has accused its Gulf neighbours of seeking to strangle its economy. The tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 per cent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund. It holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:57:00Z", "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/17/saudi-king-orders-reopening-qatar-border-pilgrims", "body": "The Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. "ahmedabadmirror.indiatimes.com"}, "url": "http://ahmedabadmirror.indiatimes.com/news/world/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims/articleshow/60102203.cms", "body": "Riyadh: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nRead Also:\n\nSaudi Arabia's Mohammed bin Salman elevated to crown prince\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. "digitaljournal.com"}, "url": "http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims/article/500210", "body": "Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari govt,\" Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. Qatar border to pilgrims", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9704619", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710921837", "source": {"id": "668", "title": "CBC News", "uri": "cbc.ca"}, "url": "http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/saudi-arabia-qatar-border-1.4250872", "body": "Saudi Arabia boosts security to protect Hajj pilgrims after 2015's deadly stampede\n\nQatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after officials in the capital, Riyadh, said the country was opening up its border and airports for those attending the annual hajj pilgrimage despite a diplomatic rift that cut travel ties.\n\nQatar welcomed the Saudi decision to open the border and provide flights for Qatari pilgrims, but saw the move as politically motivated, Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris performing the hajj, which this year runs from late August to early September. Saudi-owned al-Arabiya television and state television reported that 50 Qatari pilgrims had entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa crossing, which was opened for the first time since the four-nation boycott of Qatar began.\n\nThe pilgrims entered as guests of the Saudi king, al-Arabiya said. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from hajj and politically motivated that they allow them [in]..., we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference on a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia had already said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organizing the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the hajj, SPA said. The Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA added. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports, it added.\n\nBetween two million and three million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once in their lifetime.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing the pilgrimage and complained to the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst involving U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani had held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made, though he did not have a post in the Qatari government.\n\nSheikh Mohammed, the foreign minister, said the ruling family member had been there on a personal basis. A Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step toward removing the obstacles and difficulties [Qataris] faced during hajj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to {"id": "9851771", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711333179", "source": {"id": "766", "title": "ArkansasOnline", "uri": "arkansasonline.com"}, "url": "http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/aug/18/saudi-border-opens-to-qataris-for-hajj-/", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -- Saudi Arabia announced Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in the early 1970s.\n\nSaudi state media outlets broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, about 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision but that the measures also must include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement.\n\nQatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah.\n\nImages broadcast on Saudi media outlets showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nAbdullah, who has lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nAbdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government.\n\nThis was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nAbdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff began 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar.\n\nThe quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Persian Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave.\n\nSaudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Persian Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams.\n\nThe crisis also has strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week.\n\nSaudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Adam Schreck, Jon Gambrell and Jan M. "http://www.enca.com/world/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims-0", "body": "RIYADH - Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to hajj pilgrims, state media said on Thursday, despite a major diplomatic crisis roiling the region.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing was closed after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia, as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nQatar has denied the accusation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nREAD: Qatar rejects latest threat of 'siege countries'\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe announcement came after Prince Salman received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDoha then accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj, and of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of pilgrims.\n\n'Goodwill gesture'\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the announcement.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nThere was no immediate official reaction from Doha, but Qataris responded to the move on social media.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nREAD: Arab states vow to maintain boycotts on Qatar\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies have shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330-billion (R4.3-trillion) in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place at the beginning of September.\n\nThe pilgrimage is expected to {"id": "9780226", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711123358", "source": {"id": "3374", "title": "Hamodia", "uri": "hamodia.com"}, "url": "http://hamodia.com/2017/08/17/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-hajj-pilgrims/", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthlong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents; and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:27:00Z", "extractedDates":
