{"id": "9699444", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710908814", "source": {"id": "1454", "title": "Punch Newspapers", "uri": "punchng.com"}, "url": "http://punchng.com/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims/", "body": "Saudi Arabia on Thursday ordered the reopening of its border with Qatar to Muslim pilgrims, a move which Doha said was welcome but too little to heal relations between the feuding Gulf neighbours.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, also known as Abu Samrah, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, has been closed since June in a diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh cut ties with Doha over accusations the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the allegation and in turn accused Riyadh of restricting its citizens' right to make the hajj, or annual pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam, located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nSaudi King Salman authorised \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", state news agency SPA announced.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\".\n\nQatar's foreign minister welcomed the decision but lashed out at Riyadh's ongoing \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar or living in Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated, and the manner in which they were subsequently permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicised and which was announced with other goals in mind... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation and remain separate from our political issues.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\n- 'Right to pilgrimage' -\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has emerged as the worst political crisis to grip the region in decades.\n\nThe Saudi decision to reopen the frontier for Qatari pilgrims came shortly after the kingdom's powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met with Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nIt was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" by meeting the crown prince on Wednesday in the Saudi city of Jeddah and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Crown Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qatari pilgrims would be allowed to enter the kingdom for hajj this year but imposed several travel restrictions, including flying in only on airlines approved by Riyadh.\n\nDoha has accused Riyadh of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of Qatari citizens.\n\n\"We hope that the Saudi authorities cooperate with our government agencies to ensure the security of the Qatari people,\" the foreign minister said in Stockholm.\n\nAnalysts cautioned Thursday that the diplomatic crisis was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong opinions on social media, with many Qataris making critical comments.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"He (King Salman) didn't invite them to his own house. And every Muslim has the right to go to hajj,\" wrote another Twitter user.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, Qatar ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:39:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 2106, "textStart": 2100, "date": "-06-05", ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual haj pilgrimage, state media said Thursday, in the first signs of a thaw after the region's worst diplomatic crisis in years.\n\nThe border had been shut after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups.\n\nThe announcement came after Saudi Arabia's powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to the official Saudi Press Agency, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations after the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe even ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nSaudi Arabia had last month said that Qataris wanting to perform this year's haj would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the pilgrimage, but imposed certain restrictions including that Qatari pilgrims arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe haj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's haj. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the Kingdom's airports, SPA said.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing the pilgrimage and complained to the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst among U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years. Qatari media did not immediately carry the Saudi report.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman had no immediate comment but said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani who held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made, did not hold a position in the Qatari government.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties [Qataris] faced during hajj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Islam's holiest city for the pilgrimage each year. {"id": "9666971", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710829605", "source": {"id": "2548", "title": "Ya Libnan", "uri": "yalibnan.com"}, "url": "http://yalibnan.com/2017/08/17/saudi-king-orders-reopening-of-qatar-border-to-pilgrims-despite-rift/", "body": "Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to hajj pilgrims, state media said Thursday, despite a major diplomatic crisis roiling the region.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing was closed after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia, as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups. Qatar has denied the accusation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe announcement came after Prince Salman received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDoha then accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj, and of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of pilgrims.\n\n- 'Goodwill gesture' -\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the announcement.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nThere was no immediate official reaction from Doha, but Qataris responded to the move on social media.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies have shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place at the beginning of September.\n\nThe pilgrimage is expected to draw around two million people this year.\n\nABC\n\nYa Libnan is not responsible for the comments that are posted below. {"id": "9763648", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711075572", "source": {"id": "4566", "title": "The Daily Star", "uri": "thedailystar.net"}, "url": "http://www.thedailystar.net:80/backpage/saudis-open-border-qatar-pilgrims-1450348", "body": "Saudi Arabia yesterday ordered the reopening of its border with Qatar to Muslim pilgrims, a move which Doha said was welcome but too little to heal relations between the feuding Gulf neighbours.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, also known as Abu Samrah, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage to Makkah, has been closed since June in a diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh cut ties with Doha over accusations the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the allegation and in turn accused Riyadh of restricting its citizens' right to make the hajj, or annual pilgrimage to Makkah, the holiest site in Islam, located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nSaudi King Salman authorised \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", state news agency SPA announced.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\".\n\nQatar's foreign minister welcomed the decision but lashed out at Riyadh's ongoing \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar or living in Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated, and the manner in which they were subsequently permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicised and which was announced with other goals in mind... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation and remain separate from our political issues.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has emerged as the worst political crisis to grip the region in decades.\n\nThe Saudi decision to reopen the frontier for Qatari pilgrims came shortly after the kingdom's powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met with Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nIt was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" by meeting the crown prince on Wednesday in the Saudi city of Jeddah and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Crown Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qatari pilgrims would be allowed to enter the kingdom for hajj this year but imposed several travel restrictions, including flying in only on airlines approved by Riyadh.\n\nDoha has accused Riyadh of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Makkah by refusing to guarantee the safety of Qatari citizens.\n\n\"We hope that the Saudi authorities cooperate with our government agencies to ensure the security of the Qatari people,\" the foreign minister said in Stockholm.\n\nAnalysts cautioned yesterday that the diplomatic crisis was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the {"id": "9732906", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710993562", "source": {"id": "305", "title": "Economic Times", "uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com"}, "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-hajj-pilgrims/articleshow/60107242.cms", "body": "RIYADH: Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:27:00Z", "extractedDates": {"id": "9648204", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 108, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 542, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Dogs", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Dogs", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710782725", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/saudi-king-orders-qatar-border-reopened-pilgrims-state-224427160.html", "body": "Riyadh (AFP) - Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the reopening of the border with Qatar to hajj pilgrims, state media said Thursday, despite a major diplomatic crisis roiling the region.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing was closed after regional kingpin Saudi Arabia, as well as Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing the emirate of fostering Islamist extremist groups. Qatar has denied the accusation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe announcement came after Prince Salman received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDoha then accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj, and of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of pilgrims.\n\n- 'Goodwill gesture' -\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the announcement.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nThere was no immediate official reaction from Doha, but Qataris responded to the move on social media.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies have shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place at the beginning of September.\n\nThe pilgrimage is expected to draw around two million people this year.", "dateTime": "timeCrawl": "09:04:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Saudi king orders reopening of Qatar border to pilgrims", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9737785", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711006047", "source": {"id": "6602", "title": "WTOP", "uri": "wtop.com"}, "url": "http://wtop.com/middle-east/2017/08/saudi-arabia-to-allow-qatari-pilgrims-at-hajj-despite-rift/", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that led to both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. diplomatic crisis, has issued directions to reopen the border with Qatar to facilitate the annual hajj pilgrimage, state media reported Thursday.\n\nThe Salwa border, between the two countries, had been sealed after Saudi Arabia and allies Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) cut ties with Qatar on June 5 at diplomatic and trade level, accusing it of supporting extremism.\n\nAccording to Saudi Press Agency, an ambassador of Qatar, Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, met to Crown prince Mohmmed Bin Salman after which the announcement regarding border opening was made.\n\nThe king has permitted \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nEmphasising \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people,\" the king also ordered to send private jets belonging to Saudi airlines to Doha airport in order \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nLast month, Saudi Arabia allowed Qataris to perform hajj this year but imposed some restrictions, including the use of prescribed airlines.\n\nLater, Qatari authorities accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by denying guarantee {"id": "9708812", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710932066", "source": {"id": "566", "title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-17-ML--Qatar/id-a8af6e9867ec4bd0a8089c27c4775585", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell in Dubai and Jan M. {"id": "9710265", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710936051", "source": {"id": "8898", "title": "Twin Falls Times-News", "uri": "magicvalley.com"}, "url": "http://magicvalley.com/news/world/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-hajj-pilgrims/article_79748271-c68a-53f4-8d99-68025c1e19ca.html", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nGet news headlines sent daily to your inbox Sign Up! Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. {"id": "9814759", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711225400", "source": {"id": "6862", "title": "ARAB TIMES", "uri": "arabtimesonline.com"}, "url": "http://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/hajj-opens-border-qatar-pilgrims/", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Aug 17, (Agencies): Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the Hajj, despite a monthlong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage. The decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. The way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement.\n\nQatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment. The official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jeddah -- nearest to Makkah -- and to host them at his expense for the Hajj. Saudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday. The decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al-Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jeddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras. Sheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972. \"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard. He said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\" Sheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jeddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar.\n\nThe quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border. Mixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region. Qatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the Hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear\", particularly regarding the facilitation of Hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:19:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 28, "textStart": 22, {"id": "9705028", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710922535", "source": {"id": "19267", "title": "Seattle Pi", "uri": "seattlepi.com"}, "url": "http://www.seattlepi.com/news/world/article/Saudi-Arabia-to-allow-Qatari-pilgrims-at-hajj-11825202.php", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that led to both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Qatar has denied the accusation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe announcement came after Prince Salman received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDoha then accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj, and of jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of pilgrims.\n\n- 'Goodwill gesture' -\n\nSome observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the announcement.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based think tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nThere was no immediate official reaction from Doha, but Qataris responded to the move on social media.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies have shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place at the beginning of September.\n\nThe pilgrimage is expected to draw around two million people this year.", "dateTime": pass through, in the first step forward since the diplomatic crisis began\n\nSaudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered that the border with Qatar be reopened to allow pilgrims to carry out their annual hajj pilgrimage to Makkah, official state media said on Thursday.\n\nA statement on the official Saudi Press Agency said the Salwa border point would be open for Qatari citizens who wish to perform the annual pilgrimage to pass through with no electronic permissions needed.\n\nThe statement added that Saudi Arabia's King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has invited Qatari pilgrims to perform this year's Hajj pilgrimage at his expense, ordering private jets belonging to Saudi airlines to be sent to Doha airport.\n\nThe border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, according to a statement from the Saudi News Agency.\n\nThe decision represents the first step forward since a diplomatic crisis began when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on 5 June, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorism\".\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut as the four Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions.\n\nQatar denies the accusations.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee (NHRC) demanded on Saturday that Saudi Arabia lift all land and air restrictions on Qatar-based pilgrims traveling to Mecca for the Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nThe crown prince emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people, and between the Saudi leadership and the royal family in Qatar\", the statement added.\n\nJeddah is the airport hub for pilgrims travelling to Mecca and Medina to perform the annual Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nUnder the same royal Saudi King Orders to Open Qatar Border For Mecca Pilgrims: Report", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9737790", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711006073", "source": {"id": "5488", "title": "Reuters UK", "uri": "uk.reuters.com"}, "url": "https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-saudi-qatar-haj-idUKKCN1AW2RO", "body": "DUBAI/DOHA (Reuters) - Qatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh said it was opening up its border and airports for those attending the annual haj pilgrimage despite a diplomatic rift that cut travel ties.\n\nQatar welcomed the Saudi decision to open the border and provide flights for Qatari pilgrims, but saw the move as politically motivated, Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris performing the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi-owned al-Arabiya television and state television reported that 50 Qatari pilgrims had entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa crossing, which was opened for the first time since the four-nation boycott of Qatar began.\n\nThe pilgrims entered as guests of the Saudi king, al-Arabiya said. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from haj and politically motivated that they allow them (in)..., we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference on a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated\".\n\nSaudi Arabia had already said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nThe Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA added. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports, it added.\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once in the lifetime.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicising the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst involving U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani had held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made though he did not have a post in the Qatari government.\n\nSheikh Mohammed, the foreign minister, said the ruling family member had been there on a personal basis.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move. \"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T09:04:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.8274509906768799, {"id": "9754808", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711051414", "source": {"id": "78", "title": "NPR.org", "uri": "npr.org"}, "url": "http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/17/544157632/despite-rift-saudi-arabia-says-it-will-allow-qatari-pilgrims-to-attend-hajj", "body": "Qatar has been isolated by neighboring countries in a heated diplomatic standoff. But on Thursday, Saudi Arabia announced that it plans to open its border to allow pilgrims from the tiny Gulf country to make the annual hajj to Islam's holiest sites.\n\nThe announcement comes after a meeting between Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and a member of the Qatari royal family, Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani.\n\nAccording to a report in the Saudi state news agency, both men spoke about the \"brotherly feelings\" between the two nations -- a marked change in tone from the highly public spat in which Saudi Arabia has accused Qatar of funding terrorist organizations and has blockaded the country.\n\nThe Saudi crown prince said the country would open the Salwa border crossing to Qatari citizens who wanted to perform the hajj, without requiring them to obtain electronic permits. The hajj, a pilgrimage to Mecca required of every Muslim who can afford it and is physically able to make it at least once in their life, begins later this month and ends in early September.\n\nThe official news agency added that the Saudi king would dispatch Saudi planes to Qatar's capital, Doha, \"to fly all Qatari pilgrims at his own expense to the city of Jeddah and host them completely at the expense of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques.\"\n\nA Saudi official named Hussein Al-Sharif, undersecretary of the Ministry of Hajj and Umrah, told the Saudi broadcaster Al Arabiya that Saudi Arabia has reserved a 4,000-square-meter plot for some 2,400 Qatari pilgrims in \"the most desirable area\" along a primary hajj route.\n\nJust last month, Saudi Arabia had said pilgrims from Qatar \"would face certain restrictions if they wanted to attend the Hajj,\" according to the BBC. In response, a Qatari human rights organization complained to the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion.\n\nIt's worth noting that the Qatari royal family member who met with the Saudi crown prince does not hold an official government position and his \"branch of the family was ousted in a place coup in 1972,\" The Associated Press reports.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Gerd Nonneman, professor of international relations and Gulf studies at Georgetown University in Qatar, tells the wire service.\n\nNonnemann added that Sheikh Abdullah has lived in Saudi Arabia previously and that \"his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s.\"\n\nThere was no comment from Qatari government officials for about 12 hours after the news broke, according to the AP.\n\nAt a news conference in Sweden, Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani called it a \"step forward\" but warned that it was \"politically motivated,\" the BBC reported.\n\nSaudi Arabia's actions are being praised by regional allies such as the United Arab Emirates. The country's state minister for foreign affairs, Anwar Gargash, tweeted, \"Every day, Saudi proves how big it is, and Qatar's clamor and politicization of the hajj must end. ... to allow pilgrims to take part in the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, official state media said in Riyadh.\n\nThe decision came after the kingdom received an envoy from Doha for the first time since Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed ties with Qatar on 5 June.\n\nThe king ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage,\" said a statement from the Saudi News Agency (SPA).\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha's airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense,\" it added.\n\nSPA also said the Salwa border point would be open for Qatari citizens who wish to perform the annual pilgrimage to pass through with no electronic permissions needed.\n\nRiyadh and its allies had boycotted Qatar, accusing it of supporting terrorism, charges that Doha denies.\n\nQatar accused the Saudis of politicising Hajj during a meeting of the United Nations special rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nThe Doha-backed National Human Rights Committee (NHRC) told the UN that Qatari citizens were being told that they could only enter Saudi Arabia through two airports and that they would have to travel via the Qatari capital of Doha to be allowed in.\n\nThe NHRC said in a statement that it was \"extremely concerned over [Saudi Arabia] politicising religious rituals and using [Hajj] to achieve political gains\".\n\n\"The Saudi authorities have allowed the Qatari pilgrims to enter Saudi Arabia through two airports via Qatar There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from hajj and politically motivated that they allow them (in) ... we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference during a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia had already said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organizing the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the hajj, SPA said. The Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA added.\n\nQatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports, it added.\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst involving United States-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi {"id": "9831671", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711275022", "source": {"id": "214", "title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801628/index.html", "body": "Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (R) meets with Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Jassim al-Thani in Jeddah on August 16\n\nQatari hajj pilgrims began crossing into Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh reopened the border in a move that Doha welcomed but saw as \"politically motivated\" as regional tensions simmer.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage, has been closed since June in a major diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nAround 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe government separately allocated seven flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicisation of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\n- 'Right to pilgrimage' -\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has evolved as the worst political crisis to grip the Gulf region in decades.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts cautioned Thursday that the dispute was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, Qatar ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nburs-ac/boc", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:02:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 133,
