"dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711384170", "source": {"id": "309", "title": "news24", "uri": "news24.com"}, "url": "http://www.news24.com/World/News/saudi-arabia-reopens-border-to-qatari-pilgrims-despite-tensions-20170818", "body": "Riyadh - Qatari hajj pilgrims began crossing into Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh reopened the border in a move that Doha welcomed but saw as \"politically motivated\" as regional tensions simmer.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage, has been closed since June in a major diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nAround 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe government separately allocated seven flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision, but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicisation of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has evolved as the worst political crisis to grip the Gulf region in decades.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts cautioned on Thursday that the dispute was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically.\n\n\"We do not need the [Saudi] king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80% of them foreigners, Qatar ranks as {"id": "9694345", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710895700", "source": {"id": "15257", "title": "middle-east-online.com", "uri": "middle-east-online.com"}, "url": "http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=84388", "body": "RIYADH - Qatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh said it was opening up its border and airports for those attending the annual haj pilgrimage despite a diplomatic rift that cut travel ties.\n\nQatar welcomed the Saudi decision to open the border and provide flights for Qatari pilgrims, but saw the move as politically motivated, Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris performing the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi-owned al-Arabiya television and state television reported that 50 Qatari pilgrims had entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa crossing, which was opened for the first time since the four-nation boycott of Qatar began.\n\nThe pilgrims entered as guests of the Saudi king, al-Arabiya said. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from haj and politically motivated that they allow them (in)..., we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference on a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated\".\n\nSaudi Arabia had already said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nThe Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA added. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports, it added.\n\nCOMPLAINT Between 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once in the lifetime.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicising the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst involving U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani had held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made though he did not have a post in the Qatari government.\n\nSheikh Mohammed, the foreign minister, said the ruling family member had been there on a personal basis.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move. \"This is a step toward removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:11:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.8196078538894653, {"id": "9696211", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710900245", "source": {"id": "6076", "title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "uri": "lethbridgeherald.com"}, "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2017/08/17/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-hajj-pilgrims/", "body": "By Abdullah Al-Shihri And Aya Batrawy, The Associated Press on August 17, 2017.\n\nRIYADH, Saudi Arabia - Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighbouring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centred on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:22:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 78, "textStart": 63, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden today.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah nearest to Mecca, and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing today.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasising the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar.\n\nThe quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicised and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the UN special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year.\n\nSaudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced today, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nAt issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on today's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. {"id": "9692826", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710892523", "source": {"id": "81", "title": "TimesDaily", "uri": "timesdaily.com"}, "url": "http://www.timesdaily.com/news/nation/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-hajj-pilgrims/article_26b62d30-8489-54db-9437-4540c8959674.html", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighboring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.\n\nSubscribe", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:06:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "dateCrawl": Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. {"id": "9672544", "categories": [{"id": 328, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Aviation", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Aviation", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 542, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Dogs", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Dogs", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710841834", "source": {"id": "18917", "title": "expressnewsline.com", "uri": "expressnewsline.com"}, "url": "http://expressnewsline.com/2017/08/17/saudi-arabia-to-open-salwa-border-point-to-qatari-pilgrims.html", "body": "Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Bahrain cut diplomatic ties with Qatar and severed air, land and sea links with it on June 5 after accusing it of backing extremist groups.\n\nSaudi Arabia will open its border with Qatar to let pilgrims attend the hajj, marking a breakthrough in a monthslong rift between the two Gulf countries.\n\nKing Salman, while ordering the opening of the Salwa border crossing, also said that all Qatari citizens will be allowed to cross the border without the required electronic passes used for pilgrims.\n\n\"The Saudi authorities have allowed the Qatari pilgrims to enter Saudi Arabia through two airports via Qatar only, thus any Qatari citizen located outside Qatar must first return to Qatar then travel to Saudi Arabia\", it said.\n\nAccording to a statement from the Saudi News Agency the border decision came after the kingdom's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha. {"id": "10126578", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712097618", "source": {"id": "7948", "title": "Rappler", "uri": "rappler.com"}, "url": "http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/middle-east/179117-saudi-arabia-reopens-border-qatari-pilgrims", "body": "REOPENING. A handout picture provided by the Saudi Press Agency (SPA) shows Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (R) meeting with Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Jassim al-Thani in Jeddah on August 16, 2017. AFP PHOTO / HO / SPA RIYADH, Saudi Arabia -\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage, has been closed since June in a major diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicizing the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nAround 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe government separately allocated 7 flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicization of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicization.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\n'Right to pilgrimage'\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has evolved as the worst political crisis to grip the Gulf region in decades.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday, August 16, in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts cautioned Thursday that the dispute was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80% of them foreigners, Qatar ranks as the world's richest country on a per capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund. - Rappler.com", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T02:10:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 217, "textStart": {"id": "9693689", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710894428", "source": {"id": "1409", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "uri": "theglobeandmail.com"}, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-after-surprise-meeting/article36008600/", "body": "Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighbouring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centred on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:08:00Z", "extractedDates": {"id": "9765547", "categories": [{"id": 328, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Aviation", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Aviation", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711081107", "source": {"id": "2026", "title": "Middle East Eye", "uri": "middleeasteye.net"}, "url": "http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/qatar-welcomes-saudi-arabias-decision-reopen-borders-hajj-pilgrims-631754643", "body": "Qatar on Thursday welcomed Saudi Arabia's decision to reopen the countries' border to Hajj pilgrims, but lashed out at Riyadh's \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"The government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" said Qatar's foreign minister, Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani.\n\nHowever, he added that the original Saudi decision to close the border was political, as was the decision to reopen.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation and remain separate from our political issues,\" he said.\n\nAl Arabiya TV reported 50 Qatari pilgrims entered Saudi territory on Thursday after authorities opened the border crossing. It is the first such crossing since Saudi Arabia and three other Arab countries began a blockade on Qatar in June, over claims it supported \"terrorists\".\n\nThe Saudi king on Wednesday ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed in as his guests.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha's airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\", it added.\n\nThe Doha-backed National Human Rights Committee (NHRC) told the UN last month that Qatari citizens were being told that they could only enter Saudi Arabia through two airports and that they would have to travel via the Qatari capital of Doha to be allowed in.\n\nThe NHRC had also commented that it was \"extremely concerned over [Saudi Arabia] politicising religious rituals and using [Hajj] to achieve political gains.\n\n\"The Saudi authorities have allowed the Qatari pilgrims to enter Saudi Arabia through two airports via Qatar only, thus any Qatari citizen located outside Qatar {"id": "9704990", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710922482", "source": {"id": "497", "title": "WSOC", "uri": "wsoctv.com"}, "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-after-surprise-meeting/594125755", "body": "The decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:05:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", Qatar has denied the accusation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nThe king has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform hajj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for hajj without electronic permits\", a statement on SPA said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nThe announcement came after Prince Salman received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qataris wanting to perform this year's hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDoha then accused Riyadh of {"id": "9684713", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710871986", "source": {"id": "492", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-first-group-of-qatari-pilgrims-enter-saudi-arabia-by-land-saudi-tv-2533013", "body": "Qatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh said it was opening up its border and airports for those attending the annual haj pilgrimage despite a diplomatic rift that cut travel ties.\n\nQatar welcomed the Saudi decision to open the border and provide flights for Qatari pilgrims, but saw the move as politically motivated, Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris performing the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi-owned al-Arabiya television and state television reported that 50 Qatari pilgrims had entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa crossing, which was opened for the first time since the four-nation boycott of Qatar began.\n\nThe pilgrims entered as guests of the Saudi king, al-Arabiya said. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from haj and politically motivated that they allow them (in)..., we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference on a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated\".\n\nSaudi Arabia had already said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nThe Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA added. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports, it added.\n\nCOMPLAINT\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once in the lifetime.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicising the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst involving U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani had held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made though he did not have a post in the Qatari government.\n\nSheikh Mohammed, the foreign minister, said the ruling family member had been there on a personal basis.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move. \"This is a step toward removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency {"id": "10008999", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711755945", "source": {"id": "14218", "title": "Newsweek", "uri": "newsweek.com"}, "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/saudi-arabia-king-salman-hires-private-jets-transport-qatars-pilgrims-hajj-652101", "body": "Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered private jets to fly Qatari pilgrims on the Hajj to Mecca at his own personal expense as Riyadh and Doha continue a political standoff that started in June. Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries cut ties with Qatar and implemented an embargo on the movement of people and goods in one of the worst diplomatic crises in the region in decades.\n\nIn order to ease tensions over Qatari Muslims being able to make the pilgrimage, King Salman has chartered seven Boeing 777s, the world's largest twinjet aircraft, to fly the Qataris from Doha to the port city of Jeddah in western Saudi Arabia, according to the kingdom's official press agency. The flights, hired from Saudi Arabia's national carrier Saudia, will depart from August 22 to August 25 and return on September 5, the end of the annual Hajj prilgrimage.\n\nRead More: Saudi Arabian actress offers private planes to fly Qatari pilgrims to Islam's holy sites\n\nKeep up with this story and more by subscribing now\n\nTo ease the passage of Qatar's pilgrims to Islam's holiest city, Saudi Arabia has also reopened the Salwa border crossing with Qatar. The reopening of the crossing point, the only overland connection between the two gulf nations, will allow Qatari nationals on the Hajj to drive to the holy sites, The Wall Street Journal reported.\n\nQataris have been permitted to enter Saudi Arabia without the usual electronic permits issued to pilgrims. The first 120 crossed the border on Thursday.\n\nMuslims circle the Kaaba inside the Grand Mosque in Mecca on December 13, 2007. REUTERS/Ali Jarekji\n\nThe relaxation of restrictions for pilgrims was arranged in a meeting in Jeddah between Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali Al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling family, though the agreement on religious matters appears unlikely to lead to a wider political arrangement.\n\nMounting tensions between Qatar and its neighbors spilled over in June, when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the UAE and Bahrain all cut diplomatic ties, accusing Qatar of supporting terrorism and backing regional rival Iran. Four nations issued a list of 13 provisos for the resumption of normal relations with tiny, gas-producing Qatar, also the location of the largest U.S. military base in the region. The list of demands includes closing the Doha-based, state-funded television station Al Jazeera, severing ties with Iran and closing Turkey's air base in Qatar.\n\nDespite the schism, Qatari pilgrims to Mecca and Medina, the two holiest cities in the Muslim faith, were initially unimpeded by Saudi Arabia in their trip to the Muslim holy lands. However, in early August, Qatar said Saudi Arabia had hindered Qatari pilgrims as they made their way to the Hajj, addressing the United Nations special rapporteur on freedom of religion. In response, Riyadh accused Qatar of a \"declaration of war\" over Islam's revered sites.\n\nAs the Muslim calendar entered the five-day period of the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca at the end of August, the schism between Qatar and Saudi Arabia had become increasingly faith-based prior to the intervention by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali Al-Thani.\n\nQatar has tried to distance itself from the agreement over the entry of Qatari pilgrims, avoiding it as a political issue. One Qatari source told the Journal that Sheikh Abdullah had been acting in a private capacity when he visited Jeddah, rather than as an official government envoy.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T03:44:00Z", Qatar denies the accusations.\n\nJeddah is the airport hub for pilgrims travelling to Mecca and Medina to perform the annual Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nUnder the same royal directive, Qatari citizens will also be transported to Mecca from King Fahad airport and Ihsaa airport in the east of the country.\n\nThere has been no reaction yet by Qatar's government to the announcement.\n\nLast month, Saudi Arabia said Qataris wanting to perform this year's Hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nOPINION: GCC crisis: Why is Kuwaiti mediation not working?\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee (NHRC) demanded on Saturday that Saudi Arabia lift all land and air restrictions on Qatar-based pilgrims traveling to Mecca for the Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nSaudi Arabia, along with Egypt, Bahrain and the UAE blocked direct air and land transportation to and from Qatar, as well as closed airspace for all Qatar Airways flights after severing ties with its Gulf neighbour in June.\n\nAs part of the blockade, the Saudi-led group also asked all Qatari nationals to leave their countries.\n\nDoha did not impose similar restrictions on the four Arab nations.\n\nMuslims are expected to perform the Hajj, one of Islam's five pillars, at least once in their lifetime, provided they are fit enough and have Riyadh of politicising the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nAround 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe government separately allocated seven flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicisation of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\n- 'Right to pilgrimage' -\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has evolved as the worst political crisis to grip the Gulf region in decades.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts cautioned Thursday that the dispute was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the border reopening.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, Qatar {"id": "9740531", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711013021", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/saudi-arabia-open-border-qatar-pilgrims-qatar-media-062309632.html", "body": "By Sylvia Westall and Tom Finn\n\nDUBAI/DOHA (Reuters) - Qatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh said it was opening up its border and airports for those attending the annual haj pilgrimage despite a diplomatic rift that cut travel ties.\n\nQatar welcomed the Saudi decision to open the frontier and provide flights for Qatari pilgrims, but regarded the move as politically motivated, Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani said.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris performing the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi-owned al-Arabiya television reported that about 120 Qatari pilgrims had entered Saudi territory on Thursday through Salwa, which was opened for the first time since the four-nation boycott of Qatar began.\n\nThe pilgrims entered as guests of the Saudi king, al-Arabiya reported. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by border officials on the Qatari side of the frontier.\n\n\"Despite the fact it's been politically motivated to ban the Qatari people from haj and politically motivated that they allow them (in)..., we welcome such a step, which is a step forward to get rid of this blockade that is imposed against my country,\" Sheikh Mohammed told a news conference on a visit to Sweden.\n\nHe did not elaborate on what he meant by \"politically motivated\".\n\nSaudi Arabia had already stated that Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organizing the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can cross the frontier without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nThe Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, it added. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the kingdom's airports.\n\nCOMPLAINT\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Mecca, Islam's holiest city, for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once in the lifetime.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the worst rift involving U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani had held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made though he did not have a post in the Qatari government.\n\nSheikh Mohammed, the foreign minister, said the ruling family member had been there on a personal basis.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move. \"This is a step toward removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\n(Reporting by Ali Abdelaty in Cairo, Tom Finn in Doha, Katie Paul in Riyadh, Daniel Dickson and Anna Ringstrom in Stockholm; writing by Maha El Dahan, Sami Aboudi and Sylvia Westall; editing by William Maclean and Mark Heinrich)", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:07:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": {"id": "9686458", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710876695", "source": {"id": "19270", "title": "WBOC TV 16", "uri": "wboc.com"}, "url": "http://www.wboc.com/story/36155746/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-hajj-pilgrims", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighboring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight Thursday. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"id": "9697220", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710903007", "source": {"id": "7304", "title": "chiangraitimes.com", "uri": "chiangraitimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.chiangraitimes.com/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-after-surprise-meeting.html", "body": "Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centred on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:47:00Z", "extractedDates": {"id": "9671412", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 643, "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Islam", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Islam", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710839318", "source": {"id": "492", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-saudi-arabia-to-open-border-airports-to-qatari-pilgrims-2532860", "body": "Saudi Arabia will open a border crossing for Qataris making the haj pilgrimage and provide a plane to fly pilgrims in, despite a rift in which Saudi Arabia and other states in the region severed transport links with Qatar.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt cut transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris making the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi Arabia had said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can pass through the crossing without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nThe Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense, SPA reported. Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the Kingdom's airports, SPA said.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst among U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years. Qatari media did not immediately carry the Saudi report.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman had no immediate comment but said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani who held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made, did not hold a position in the Qatari government.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Islam's holiest city for the pilgrimage each year. Every able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "dateTime": Qatar denies the accusations.\n\nUnder the same royal directive, Qatari citizens will also be transported to Mecca from King Fahad airport and Ihsaa airport in the east of the country.\n\nThe Montreal-based International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has been working with \"various Middle Eastern states to ensure equitable access to airspace for Qatar-registered aircraft\" since
