{"id": "9687473", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710879671", "source": {"id": "2530", "title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/world/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-to-allow-pilgrims-to-attend-hajj-3941873.html", "body": "Riyadh: Saudi Arabia said on Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a months-long rift between the neighbouring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicising the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's foreign minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden on Thursday.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nFile image of Qatar's foreign minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani. Reuters\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj. Saudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late on Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasising the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar.\n\nThe quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement on Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicised and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the UN special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year.\n\nSaudi Arabia's foreign minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced on Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nAt issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on Thursday's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj\". UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 17, 2017 05:43 pm | Updated Date: Aug 17, 2017 05:43 pm\n\nTags "url": "http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2017/08/19/2003676798", "body": "Qatari pilgrims on Thursday began crossing into Saudi Arabia, Saudi media reported, after Riyadh reopened the border in a move that Doha welcomed, but saw as \"politically motivated\" as regional tensions simmer.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj, has been closed since June in a major diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicizing the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to Mecca, the holiest site in Islam that is located in western Saudi Arabia.\n\nAbout 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after Saudi Arabia's King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe Saudi government separately allocated seven flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA reported.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision, but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicization of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated ... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Minister of Foreign Affairs Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicization,\" he said.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the border came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a telephone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts on Thursday said that the dispute was far from over.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari\" government, Ali Shihabi of Qatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the Kingdom's airports, SPA said.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicizing the pilgrimage and complained to the U.N. Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst among U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years. Qatari media did not immediately carry the Saudi report.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman had no immediate comment but said Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani who held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman before the announcement was made, did not hold a position in the Qatari government.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nBetween 2 million and 3 million Muslims from around the world travel to Islam's holiest city for the pilgrimage each year. {"id": "9744330", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711022604", "source": {"id": "78", "title": "NPR.org", "uri": "npr.org"}, "url": "http://www.npr.org/2017/08/17/544157632/despite-rift-saudi-arabia-says-it-will-allow-qatari-pilgrims-to-attend-hajj", "body": "Qatar has been isolated by neighboring countries in a heated diplomatic standoff. But on Thursday, Saudi Arabia announced it plans to open its border to allow pilgrims from the tiny Gulf country to attend the annual hajj to Islam's holiest sites.\n\nThe announcement comes after a meeting between Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and a member of the Qatari royal family, Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani.\n\nAccording to a report in the Saudi state news agency, both men spoke about the \"brotherly feelings\" between the two nations -- a marked change in tone from the highly public spat in which Saudi has accusing Qatar of funding terrorist organizations and is blockading the country.\n\nThe Saudi crown prince said the country would open the Salwa border crossing to Qatari citizens who wanted to perform the hajj, without requiring them to obtain electronic permits. The hajj begins later this month and ends in early September.\n\nThe official news agency added that the Saudi king would dispatch Saudi planes to Qatar's capital, Doha, \"to fly all Qatari pilgrims at his own expense to the city of Jeddah and host them completely at the expense of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques.\"\n\nA Saudi official named Hussein Al-Sharif, undersecretary of the Ministry of Hajj and Umrah, told the Saudi broadcaster Al Arabiya that Saudi has reserved a 4,000 square meter plot for some 2,400 Qatari pilgrims in \"the most desirable area\" along a primary hajj route.\n\nJust last month, Saudi had said pilgrims from Qatar \"would face certain restrictions if they wanted to attend the Hajj,\" according to the BBC. In response, a Qatari human rights organization complained to the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion.\n\nIt's worth noting that the Qatari royal family member who met with the Saudi crown prince does not hold an official government position and his \"branch of the family was ousted in a place coup in 1972,\" The Associated Press reports.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Gerd Nonneman, professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar, tells the wire service.\n\nNonnemann added that Sheikh Abdullah has lived in Saudi previously and \"his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s.\"\n\nThere was no comment from Qatari government officials for about 12 hours after the news broke, according to the AP.\n\nAt a news conference in Sweden, Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani called it a \"step forward\" but warned that it was \"politically motivated,\" the BBC reported.\n\nSaudi Arabia's actions are being praised by regional allies such as the UAE. The country's State Minister for Foreign Affairs Anwar Gargash tweeted, \"Every day, Saudi proves how big it is, and Qatar's clamor and politicization of the hajj must end. ... {"id": "9684256", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710870636", "source": {"id": "1679", "title": "Deccan Herald", "uri": "deccanherald.com"}, "url": "http://www.deccanherald.com/content/628515/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border.html", "body": "The decision was taken after Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Sheikh Mohammaed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani.\n\nSaudi Arabia said today it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighbouring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicising the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden today.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah \u00e2\u20ac\" nearest to Mecca, and to host them at his expense for the hajj. Saudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing today.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\"\n\nSaudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasising the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar.\n\nThe quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicised and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the UN special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year.\n\nSaudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced today, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nAt issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on today's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:20:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": {"id": "9803666", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 291, "label": "dmoz/News/Media", "uri": "dmoz/News/Media", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 292, "label": "dmoz/News/Media/Services", "uri": "dmoz/News/Media/Services", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711191835", "source": {"id": "2989", "title": "The Detroit News", "uri": "detroitnews.com"}, "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2017/08/17/qatar-saudi-arabia-hajj-pilgrims/104704210/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nRiyadh, Saudi Arabia -- Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj, despite a monthslong rift between Doha and four Arab countries led by Riyadh that prompted both sides to trade accusations of politicizing the pilgrimage.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nSaudi state media broke the news overnight. Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed on Thursday by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, some 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived previously for some years in Saudi Arabia and has gone back on private visits, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710873055", "source": {"id": "5866", "title": "Premium Times Nigeria", "uri": "premiumtimesng.com"}, "url": "http://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/world-foreign/240560-saudi-arabia-open-border-airports-qatari-pilgrims.html", "body": "Saudi Arabia will open a border crossing for Qataris making the haj pilgrimage and provide a plane to fly pilgrims in, in spite of a rift in which Saudi Arabia and other states in the region severed transport links with Qatar.\n\nSaudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt cut transport links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris making the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi Arabia had said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can pass through the crossing without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nSPA reported that Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense.\n\nQatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the Kingdom's airports, SPA said.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicising the pilgrimage and complained to the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst among U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nQatari media did not immediately carry the Saudi report.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman had no immediate comment but said Qatari Abdullah Al-Thani who held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman before the announcement was made, did not hold a position in the Qatari government.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nBetween two and guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, maritime and land links with Qatar, and imposed economic sanctions, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorists\" and of being too close to their regional nemesis Iran.\n\nQatar denied the allegations and denounced what it called a \"blockade\" aimed at bringing the wealthy emirate to its knees.\n\nThe tiny emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, ranks as the world's richest on a per-capita basis, according to the International Monetary Fund.\n\nIt holds a staggering $330 billion in a sovereign wealth fund, with assets heavily invested abroad.\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once in a lifetime, is to take place this year at the beginning of September.\n\nMore than 1.8 million faithful took part in last year's hajj. {"id": "9673831", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710845017", "source": {"id": "8355", "title": "World Bulletin", "uri": "worldbulletin.net"}, "url": "http://www.worldbulletin.net/middle-east/193039/saudi-king-offers-to-host-qatar-pilgrims-at-own-expense", "body": "Saudi King Salman bin Abdul Aziz has ordered that Hajj pilgrims from Qatar be allowed to enter Saudi Arabia, where he has offered to host them at his own expense.\n\nThe move follows accusations that Saudi authorities were hindering the entry of Qatari pilgrims into Saudi Arabia, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims are set to perform the Hajj pilgrimage later this month.\n\nSince early June, Qatar has been the target of a land, sea and air embargo by a four-nation bloc of Arab states led by Saudi Arabia.\n\nIn an apparent response to the accusations, the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported late Wednesday that King Salman had \"agreed to recommendations made by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman regarding the entry of Qatari pilgrims into the [Saudi] kingdom via the Salwa land border crossing to perform the Hajj\".\n\nThe king, the news agency added, had consented to allow \"all Qatari citizens who wish to perform the Hajj [into the kingdom] without required electronic permits\".\n\nAccording to the SPA, the king's decision was \"based on the mediation efforts of Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling family who was received by bin Salman in Jeddah on Wednesday\".\n\nThe news agency went on to report that King Salman had dispatched a Saudi Airlines aircraft to Doha's international airport \"to transport all Qatari pilgrims at his own expense to the city of Jeddah\".\n\nLast month, Qatar's National Human Rights Committee told the UN's special rapporteur on religious freedom that Hajj pilgrims from Qatar were being discriminated against by the Saudi authorities.\n\nCommittee head Ali bin Smeikh al-Marri called on the Saudi authorities to \"facilitate Hajj procedures and remove restrictions\" facing Qatari pilgrims.\n\nOn June 5, four Arab states -- including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Emirates and Bahrain -- abruptly cut diplomatic ties with Qatar, accusing it of supporting terrorism.\n\nSaudi Arabia also closed its land border with Qatar, geographically isolating the tiny Gulf state.\n\nDoha, for its part, strenuously denies accusations that it supports terrorism, describing attempts to isolate it as \"unjustified\" and in breach of international law.", "dateTime": to Mecca.\n\nThe decision came after the kingdom received an envoy from Doha for the first time since Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed ties with Qatar in June.\n\nKing Salman also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\".\n\nLast month, Qatar accused the Saudis of politicising hajj and addressed the United Nations Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion, expressing concern about obstacles facing Qataris wanting to attend hajj.\n\nSaudi Arabia and its Arab allies shut down air, {"id": "9683446", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710868592", "source": {"id": "6076", "title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "uri": "lethbridgeherald.com"}, "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2017/08/17/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-after-surprise-meeting/", "body": "By Abdullah Al-Shihri And Aya Batrawy, The Associated Press on August 17, 2017.\n\nRIYADH, Saudi Arabia - Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighbouring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden on Thursday.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated. At issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on Thursday's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:15:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 78, "textStart": 63, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": "12:15:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Saudi Arabia reopens Qatar border after surprise meeting - The Lethbridge Herald - News and Sports from around Lethbridge", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9692422", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710891678", "source": {"id": "91", "title": "The New York Times", "uri": "nytimes.com"}, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/08/17/world/middleeast/ap-ml-qatar.html", "body": "The way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to an Associated Press request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. The king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah, who's lived mostly in Saudi Arabia in recent years, has no role in government and his last position was as head of the equestrian and camel racing federation in the 1970s and 1980s, said Gerd Nonneman, a professor of International Relations and Gulf Studies at Georgetown University in Qatar.\n\nSheikh Abdullah's grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\n\"He's certainly not an envoy of the Qatari government. This was not a deal that was struck,\" Nonneman said, describing it as a Saudi \"propaganda ploy\" to catch the Qatari government off-guard.\n\nHe said Saudi outreach to various individuals within Qatar's large royal family causes discomfort and \"needles the Qatari leadership.\"\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari royal in Saudi Arabia since a political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and the three Gulf countries ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nMixed-nationality families in the Gulf were affected by the measures, and Qatari students in the Gulf countries were pulled out of final exams. The crisis has also strained traditional kinships in the region.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe statement also called \"for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar.\"\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated.\n\nBahrain on Wednesday said it was investigating an alleged telephone call between Qatar's prime minister and Ali Salman, a Bahraini Shiite opposition leader who is serving a nine-year prison sentence for his role in the country's 2011 protests. Bahrain's public prosecutor said the alleged call centered on how to \"exacerbate (tensions) and undermine Bahrain's interests and stability.\"\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. "uri": "711122949", "source": {"id": "611", "title": "The Straits Times", "uri": "straitstimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/world/united-states/s-arabia-to-open-border-airports-to-qatari-pilgrims", "body": "Haj move could be first sign of diplomatic thaw, but observers say crisis far from over\n\nRIYADH * Qatari pilgrims began arriving in Saudi Arabia yesterday after Saudi King Salman ordered the reopening of the border with the emirate to facilitate the annual haj pilgrimage, in the first sign of a thaw after the worst diplomatic crisis in the Gulf in years.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing has been closed since June 5, when Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar over accusations the emirate fostered Islamist extremists.\n\nQatar has denied the allegation.\n\nThe announcement to reopen the frontier for Qatari pilgrims came after the powerful Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman received an envoy from Doha, the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said, in the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nKing Salman has allowed \"the entry of Qatari pilgrims to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia through Salwa border crossing to perform haj, and to allow all Qatari nationals who wish to enter for haj without electronic permits\", a statement on the SPA website said.\n\nHe also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims at his expense\".\n\nThe decision also came after Prince Mohammed received a phone call from United States Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis, SPA reported, without revealing the details of the conversation.\n\nSaudi Arabia last month said Qatari pilgrims would be allowed to enter the kingdom for the haj this year but imposed clear restrictions, including flying via airlines approved by Riyadh.\n\nDoha has accused Riyadh of politicising the haj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee the safety of Qatari citizens.\n\nThe haj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place at the beginning of next month. The pilgrimage is expected to draw around two million people this year.\n\nPrince Mohammed emphasised the \"historical relations between Saudi and Qatari people\" after his meeting with the Qatari envoy, Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim al-Thani, SPA said.\n\nBut some observers cautioned that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the apparent bonhomie.\n\n\"This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari (government),\" Mr Ali Shihabi of Washington-based think-tank Arabia Foundation said on Twitter, referring to the reopening of the border.\n\nA Qatari government spokes- man also appeared to downplay any breakthrough, saying the envoy did not have a post in the government.\n\nQatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed said the envoy had been in Riyadh on a personal basis.\n\nWhile welcoming the latest Saudi decision, the minister also lashed out at the \"politicisation\" of the haj.\n\nAGENCE {"id": "9765566", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711081123", "source": {"id": "1126", "title": "Anadolu Ajans\u0131", "uri": "aa.com.tr"}, "url": "http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/saudi-king-offers-to-host-qatar-pilgrims-at-own-expense/886452", "body": "Move follows accusations that Saudi authorities were hindering entry of Hajj pilgrims from Qatar\n\nSaudi King Salman bin Abdul Aziz has ordered that Hajj pilgrims from Qatar be allowed to enter Saudi Arabia, where he has offered to host them at his own expense.\n\nThe move follows accusations that Saudi authorities were hindering the entry of Qatari pilgrims into Saudi Arabia, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims are set to perform the Hajj pilgrimage later this month.\n\nSince early June, Qatar has been the target of a land, sea and air embargo by a four-nation bloc of Arab states led by Saudi Arabia.\n\nIn an apparent response to the accusations, the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported late Wednesday that King Salman had \"agreed to recommendations made by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman regarding the entry of Qatari pilgrims into the [Saudi] kingdom via the Salwa land border crossing to perform the Hajj\".\n\nThe king, the news agency added, had consented to allow \"all Qatari citizens who wish to perform the Hajj [into the kingdom] without required electronic permits\".\n\nAccording to the SPA, the king's decision was \"based on the mediation efforts of Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling family who was received by bin Salman in Jeddah on Wednesday\".\n\nThe news agency went on to report that King Salman had dispatched a Saudi Airlines aircraft to Doha's international airport \"to transport all Qatari pilgrims at his own expense to the city of Jeddah\".\n\nLast month, Qatar's National Human Rights Committee told the UN's special rapporteur on religious freedom that Hajj pilgrims from Qatar were being discriminated against by the Saudi authorities.\n\nCommittee head Ali bin al-Marri called on the Saudi authorities to \"facilitate Hajj procedures and remove restrictions\" facing Qatari pilgrims.\n\nOn June 5, four Arab states -- including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Emirates and Bahrain -- abruptly cut diplomatic ties with Qatar, accusing it of supporting terrorism.\n\nSaudi Arabia also closed its land border with Qatar, geographically isolating the tiny Gulf state.\n\nDoha, for its part, strenuously denies accusations that it supports {"id": "9811847", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711217408", "source": {"id": "9503", "title": "Middle East Monitor", "uri": "middleeastmonitor.com"}, "url": "https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20170818-qatar-welcomes-saudi-decision-to-open-borders-to-pilgrims/", "body": "An aerial view of Mount Arafat as Hajj pilgrims continue to flood onto sacred mountain in Mecca, Saudi Arabia on September 11, 2016\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani, announced on Thursday that his country welcomes Saudi Arabia's decision to open the land border to Qatari pilgrims but also criticized what he saw as a \"politicization\" of pilgrimage.\n\nIn a joint press conference in Stockholm with his Swedish counterpart, Margot Wallstrom, Al-Thani stated, \"regardless of the fact that the pilgrimage was prohibited for Qataris for political reasons, we do welcome this decision.\"\n\nOn a similar note, the Qatari National Human Rights Commission (QNH) expressed on Thursday its satisfaction with Saudi Arabia's decision to open the land border as well as the direct air route in order to transport the Qatari pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.\n\nOn Sunday evening, Salman bin Abdul-Aziz, Saudi Arabia's king, called the Qatari pilgrims to enter the kingdom through their \"Salwa\" border crossing, without any electronic permits. He also allowed direct flights from Doha as long as Qatar Airways does not operate them, according to the newest development in the pilgrims' issue that occurred in the wake of the Gulf crisis.\n\nThe National Human Rights Committee in Qatar said in a statement that it \"is deeply satisfied with the decision of the Saudi authorities\" and considers it \"a step forward to remove all obstacles and difficulties that have been facing the Qatari pilgrims this year\".\n\nThe committee added that \"since the beginning of the siege, it demanded the facilitation of the pilgrimage procedures for citizens and residents of Qatar, without the imposition of any obstacles or restrictions. The demands have been accompanied by regional and international efforts to lift any injustice towards the pilgrims and in order to refrain from any politicization of the pilgrimage or its use as a way to punish people or put pressure on governments.\"\n\nSince 5 June, Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt have cut diplomatic ties with Qatar. The first three countries have imposed measures that they perceive as a \"boycott\", whereas Doha perceives them as a \"siege\", after it has been accused of supporting terrorism, which it denies, saying that it is facing a campaign of fabricated lies that aims at imposing \"guardianship\" and threatens its sovereignty.\n\nThe Qatari Human Rights Committee stressed that \"the issue of pilgrimage cannot be subjected to any personal or political calculations, and that it is an inherent right enshrined in all international conventions and international human rights conventions as well as in the Islamic law.\"\n\nThe committee considered that \"the decision of the Saudi authorities is still ambiguous, especially when it comes to the non-Qatari pilgrims who reside in Qatar\". It also demanded that \"measures to facilitate their pilgrimage be taken without discrimination and that more measures be implemented to completely lift the siege on the citizens, residents of Qatar, as well as the citizens of the Gulf Cooperation Council countries.\n\nPrior to the decision of the Saudi King, the Kingdom required that Qatari pilgrims travel only by air, onboard of any airline company, as long as it is not Qatar Airways.\n\nQatar accused Saudi Arabia then of making pilgrimage for Qataris impossible and full of obstacles, which Riyadh denies. This comes amid exchanged accusations of using pilgrimage as a tool to increase the pressure on Qatar during the Gulf crisis.\n\nAl-Arabiya TV Channel reported that 50 Qatari pilgrims have entered the Saudi territories to perform Hajj after the authorities opened the Salwa border crossing for the first time since the diplomatic dispute erupted between the two countries back in June.\n\nAl-Arabiya "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Saudi Arabia to allow Qatari pilgrims at hajj despite rift", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9670936", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710838341", "source": {"id": "191", "title": "WMC Action News 5", "uri": "wmcactionnews5.com"}, "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36155746/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-after-surprise-meeting", "body": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighboring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden on Thursday.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah - nearest to Mecca - and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated. At issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on Thursday's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "http://www.iran-daily.com/News/198821.html", "body": "Saudi Arabia has announced it would open the Salwa border crossing to Qatari pilgrims for the annual hajj pilgrimage to the city of Mecca\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister on Thursday welcomed Saudi Arabia's decision to reopen the two countries' border to Muslim pilgrims -- while lashing out at Riyadh's \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms, Hindustantimes reported.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar or living in Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated, and the manner in which they were subsequently permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicised and which was announced with other goals in mind... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj (pilgrimage), and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicisation and remain separate from our political issues,\" Sheikh Mohammed said.\n\nSaudi Arabia has announced it would open the Salwa border crossing to Qatari pilgrims for the annual hajj pilgrimage to the city of Mecca, the birthplace of the Prophet Mohamed and Islam's holiest site, in the west of the kingdom.\n\nThe crossing had been sealed off for more than two months as a diplomatic crisis between the Saudi and Qatari governments has seen severe restrictions on travel imposed on citizens across the region.\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt announced a cut in ties with Qatar, recalled ambassadors and sealed off borders and airspace to the emirate over allegations Doha backed Islamist extremists and was too close to Iran.\n\nQatar has denied the allegations.\n\nRiyadh's decision to reopen the border came hours after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met on Wednesday with Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al-Thani, a member of the ruling dynasty in Doha.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" by meeting the crown prince in the Saudi city of Jeddah and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nDoha has consistently accused Riyadh of politicising the hajj and Qatar did not officially comment on the deal until its foreign minister was pressed by reporters during a briefing in Sweden, 12 hours later.\n\nForeign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade.\n\nThe way in which the deal was reached and announced out of Saudi Arabia raised questions about the level of the Qatari government's involvement. Qatari officials did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense. {"id": "9682881", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710867552", "source": {"id": "1223", "title": "Brownsville Herald", "uri": "brownsvilleherald.com"}, "url": "http://www.brownsvilleherald.com/news/us_world/article_49b2bf4d-9f4b-523c-96c8-cc0f0ab66ff5.html", "body": "The decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden on Thursday.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated. At issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on Thursday's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\n-- -- --\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:13:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", links with Qatar in June and imposed sanctions, accusing it of supporting Islamist militants and Iran, which Doha denies.\n\nThe state-run Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said the Salwa border point would be open for Qataris making the haj, which this year runs from late August to early September.\n\nSaudi Arabia had said Qatari pilgrims would not be affected by the travel restrictions, but some Qataris have said they faced difficulties organising the trip.\n\nQatari pilgrims can pass through the crossing without the permits usually needed to be obtained in advance for the haj, SPA said.\n\nSPA reported that Saudi king has ordered the dispatch of a Saudi Airlines plane to fly Qatari pilgrims to Jeddah at his own expense.\n\nQatari pilgrims would also be able to pass through two of the Kingdom's airports, SPA said.\n\nQatar had accused Saudi Arabia of politicising the pilgrimage and complained to the UN Special Rapporteur on freedom of religion last month.\n\nIt was not clear how far the opening of the border to pilgrims would go to help heal the rift, the worst among U.S-allied Gulf Arab countries for years.\n\nQatari media did not immediately carry the Saudi report.\n\nA Qatari government spokesman had no immediate comment but said Qatari Abdullah Al-Thani who held talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman before the announcement was made, did not hold a position in the Qatari government.\n\nA Qatari semi-government rights body gave a cautious welcome to the Saudi move.\n\n\"This is a step towards removing the obstacles and difficulties (Qataris) faced during haj procedures this year,\" the National Human Rights Committee said in a statement.\n\nSome Qataris said that even with permission to enter Saudi Arabia they would be concerned for their safety.\n\n\"I think it is very risky to go to Mecca this year, there could be hate crimes against Qataris,\" said Fatima al-Mohannadi, a Qatari student.\n\nBetween two and three million Muslims from around the world travel to Islam's holiest city for the pilgrimage each year.\n\nEvery able-bodied Muslim is supposed to undertake it at least once.(Reuters/NAN)", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T12:13:00Z", "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Aviation", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Aviation", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710976824", "source": {"id": "2018", "title": "The Financial Express Online Version", "uri": "thefinancialexpress-bd.com"}, "url": "http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2017/08/17/80051/King-Salman-invites-Qatar-pilgrims-to-perform-Hajj", "body": "RIYADH, Aug 17 (Agencies): Saudi Arabia will open its land border with Qatar to allow Hajj pilgrims to pass through, its official press agency said.\n\nA statement on the official Saudi Press Agency on Thursday said the Salwa border point would be open for Qatari citizens who wish to perform the annual pilgrimage to pass through with no electronic permissions needed.\n\nThe statement added that Saudi Arabia's King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has invited Qatari pilgrims to perform this year's Hajj pilgrimage at his expense.\n\nKing Salman also ordered that private jets belonging to Saudi airlines be sent to Doha airport \"to bring all Qatari pilgrims on his expenses\".\n\nMeanwhile, the Qatari foreign minister on Thursday welcomed Saudi Arabia's decision to reopen the two countries' border to Muslim pilgrims, while lashing out at Riyadh's \"politicisation\" of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which Qataris were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politicised, and the manner in which they were again permitted to make the pilgrimage, which was also politicised... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar on June 5, accusing Doha of supporting \"terrorism\". Qatar denies the accusations.\n\nJeddah is the airport hub for pilgrims travelling to Mecca and Medina to perform the annual Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nUnder the same royal directive, Qatari citizens will also be transported to Mecca from King Fahad airport and Ihsaa airport in the east of the country.\n\nLast month, Saudi Arabia said Qataris wanting to perform this year's Hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nQatari authorities had subsequently accused Saudi Arabia of politicising Hajj and jeopardising the pilgrimage to Mecca by refusing to guarantee their pilgrims' safety.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee (NHRC) welcomed the Saudi decision to reopen the land border, but considered it vague, especially concerning the pilgrims residing in Qatar.\n\nNHRC, in a statement on Thursday, demanded that all pilgrims get the same treatment and services without discrimination.\n\n\"The NHRC emphasises that the Hajj cannot be used for political and personal calculations or mediations, rather, it is a right guaranteed by international agreements on Human Rights and Islamic law,\" it said.\n\nThe rights group had demanded on Saturday that Saudi Arabia lift all land and air restrictions on Qatar-based pilgrims traveling to Mecca for the Hajj {"id": "9720180", "categories": [{"id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 328, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Aviation", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Aviation", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710959708", "source": {"id": "405", "title": "Business Standard", "uri": "business-standard.com"}, "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/saudi-arabia-reopens-qatar-border-for-haj-pilgrims-117081701154_1.html", "body": "Saudi Arabia announced on Thursday that it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qatari pilgrims attend the Haj, the state media reported.\n\nThe Salwa border crossing had been shut after Saudi Arabia, along with the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Egypt and Bahrain severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in June, accusing it of supporting and funding Islamist extremist groups.\n\nAccording to the Saudi Press Agency (SPA), the announcement to reopen the border for Qatari pilgrims came after the Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatar's Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani, in the first high-level public encounter between the countries since the crisis erupted.\n\nQatari pilgrims wishing to attend the Haj will be able to pass through the Salwa border crossing without needing electronic permits, a statement on the SPA said. The pilgrims would also be welcome through Saudi Arabia's airports, it added.\n\n\"All Qatari pilgrims be transported from King Fahad International Airport in Dammam and Al-Ahsa International Airport as his (King Salman) guests. All expenses are to be paid for by the King, under the Programme of the Guests of Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud for Haj and Umrah,\" the statement said.\n\nSaudi state TV said 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nIn July, Saudi Arabia had warned Qatari pilgrims would face certain restrictions if they wanted to the attend the Haj. Qatar responded by accusing Riyadh of politicising the Haj and the UN special rapporteur on freedom of religion expressed concern at Saudi Arabia's measures, BBC reported\n\nIn a statement carried by SPA, the Crown Prince thanked Sheikh Al Thani \"for his brotherly feelings\" as he stressed \"the depth of historical relations\" between Saudis and Qataris.\n\nObservers say that, despite this goodwill gesture, the dispute between Qatar and its neighbours, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Egypt and the UAE is far from over, the BBC report said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard "iran-daily.com", "uri": "iran-daily.com"}, "url": "http://www.iran-daily.com/News/198870.html", "body": "The Salwa border crossing, a key passage for Muslims on the annual hajj pilgrimage, has been closed since June in a major diplomatic crisis that saw Riyadh and its regional allies cut relations with Doha over allegations that the emirate supported terrorists, AFP reported.\n\nQatar has denied the charge and in turn accused Riyadh of politicizing the hajj by restricting its citizens from making the pilgrimage to the holy Mecca.\n\nAround 120 Qataris entered Saudi territory on Thursday through the Salwa border, also known as Abu Samrah, Saudi state television reported, after King Salman called for the border to be opened for pilgrims without electronic permits.\n\nThe government separately allocated seven flights of the Saudi national carrier to bring pilgrims from Doha at the monarch's expense, state news agency SPA announced.\n\nQatar welcomed the decision but also lashed out at what it called Riyadh's politicization of religious freedoms.\n\n\"Regardless of the manner in which pilgrims from Qatar were banned from the pilgrimage, which was politically motivated... the government of Qatar welcomes the decision and will respond positively,\" Qatari Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\n\"What matters to us is the bottom line, which is that our citizens now have a way to attend the hajj, and we uphold our demand that hajj be spared politicization.\"\n\nThe hajj, a pillar of Islam that capable Muslims must perform at least once, is to take place this year at the start of September and it is expected to draw around two million Muslims from around the world.\n\nOn June 5, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates severed diplomatic and trade ties with Qatar in what has evolved as the worst political crisis to grip the Persisn Gulf region in decades.\n\nThe kingdom's decision to reopen the frontier came shortly after its powerful Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met Qatari envoy Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani, a member of Qatar's ruling dynasty.\n\nThe meeting on Wednesday in the Saudi Red Sea city of Jeddah was the first public high-level encounter between the nations since the crisis erupted more than two months ago.\n\nThe Qatari foreign minister, however, said that Sheikh Abdullah had acted on a \"personal initiative\" and not on behalf of the Doha government.\n\nThe decision also came after SPA reported that Prince Mohammed had received a phone call from US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who has sought repeatedly to defuse the regional crisis.\n\nAnalysts cautioned Thursday that the dispute was far from over.\n\nThe decision also drew strong comments on social media, with many Qataris reacting critically.\n\n\"We do not need the (Saudi) king's charity. The Qatari right to pilgrimage is not given as charity from the king,\" one Qatari wrote on Twitter.\n\nA tiny gas-rich emirate with a population of 2.6 million, 80 percent of them foreigners, Qatar {"id": "9669741", "categories": [{"id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 42, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human Rights and Liberties", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Human_Rights_and_Liberties", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710835521", "source": {"id": "18458", "title": "WRAL.com", "uri": "wral.com"}, "url": "http://www.wral.com/saudi-arabia-to-allow-qatari-pilgrims-at-hajj-despite-rift/16886133/", "body": "You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters\n\nBy ABDULLAH AL-SHIHRI and AYA BATRAWY, Associated Press\n\nRIYADH, Saudi Arabia -- Saudi Arabia said Thursday it is reopening its border with Qatar to allow Qataris to attend the hajj amid a monthslong rift between the neighboring countries that led to both sides trading accusations of politicizing the ritual.\n\nThe decision came after Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman held a surprise meeting with a Qatari royal family member whose branch of the family was ousted in a palace coup in 1972.\n\nQatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said he welcomed the Saudi decision, but that the measures must also include a full lifting of the blockade. He was responding to questions at a press conference in Sweden on Thursday.\n\nThe official Saudi Press Agency reported that Qatari pilgrims will be allowed to enter the kingdom by land and that pilgrims would then be flown onward from two Saudi airports in Dammam and al-Ahsa at the king's expense.\n\nThe king also ordered that aircraft from the country's flagship carrier be dispatched to Qatar's capital, Doha, to fly Qatari pilgrims to the Red Sea city of Jiddah -- nearest to Mecca -- and to host them at his expense for the hajj.\n\nSaudi state TV said already 100 Qataris had arrived at the border crossing on Thursday.\n\nThe decision came after Prince Mohammed met with Qatari royal family member Sheikh Abdullah Al Thani late Wednesday at a palace in Jiddah. Images broadcast on Saudi media showed the two men seated and smiling for cameras.\n\nSheikh Abdullah was quoted as telling the Saudi prince that the ties between the two countries \"are brotherly relations rooted in history.\" Saudi Arabia's crown prince responded in kind, emphasizing the historical ties between the two royal families, according to the Saudi Press Agency.\n\nIt was not clear, however, in what capacity Sheikh Abdullah was representing the Qatari government during the meeting. His grandfather, father and brother were rulers of Qatar until a palace coup ousted his branch of the royal family in 1972.\n\nThe meeting in Jiddah was the first by a Qatari to Saudi Arabia since a tense political standoff erupted 10 weeks ago when the kingdom, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt severed ties with Qatar. The quartet also halted direct flights, expelled Qatari residents and ordered their citizens in Qatar to leave. Saudi Arabia sealed Qatar's only land border.\n\nQatar's National Human Rights Committee issued a brief statement Thursday responding to what it said were \"reports in Saudi media\" outlining the kingdom's measures for Qatari pilgrims. The statement noted that the agreement does not include allowing Qatar Airways flights carrying pilgrims.\n\nThe committee expressed its \"satisfaction\" with the decisions, but reiterated its demands that the hajj not be politicized and said the Saudi measures remain \"unclear,\" particularly regarding the facilitation of hajj for foreigners residing in Qatar.\n\nThe committee also reiterated \"calls for further measures to lift the siege entirely on citizens and residents of Qatar,\" the statement said.\n\nQatar's human rights committee had previously filed a complaint with the U.N. special rapporteur on freedom of belief and religion over restrictions placed on its nationals who wanted to attend the hajj this year. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said Qatar's complaint amounted to a \"declaration of war\" against the kingdom's management of the holy sites.\n\nDespite the goodwill measure announced Thursday, tensions remain. The quartet accuses the small Gulf nation of supporting extremists. Qatar denies the allegation and says the charges are politically motivated. At issue is Qatar's support for Islamist opposition groups in the region, which Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Egypt view as a threat.\n\nA top Emirati official, commenting on Thursday's breakthrough, called on Qatar to \"end its politicization of hajj.\" UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, also used the opportunity on Twitter to commend Saudi Arabia for the initiative to send planes.\n\nHundreds of thousands of pilgrims from around the world have already arrived in Saudi Arabia for the hajj, which begins late next week. Saudi Arabia prides itself on hosting millions of pilgrims annually at Islam's holiest sites in Mecca and Medina.\n\n___\n\nBatrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writers Adam Schreck and Jon Gambrell contributed from Dubai.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T11:02:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", transport connections with the country.\n\nThe king ordered that Qatari pilgrims be allowed \"to enter Saudi Arabia through the border crossing to do the pilgrimage\", said a statement from the Saudi News Agency.\n\nJeddah is the airport hub for pilgrims travelling to Mecca and Medina to perform the annual Hajj pilgrimage.\n\nKing Salman has ordered the transport of all Qatari pilgrims from King Fahad International Airport in Dammam as well as Al Ahsa International Airport be done free of charge and part of the King Salman bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud Program for Haj and Umrah.\n\nThe Montreal-based International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has been working with \"various Middle Eastern states to ensure equitable access to airspace for Qatar-registered aircraft\" since sanctions were announced on June 5, ICAO spokesman Anthony Philbin said.\n\nLast month, Saudi Arabia said Qataris wanting to perform this year's Hajj would be allowed to enter the kingdom, but imposed certain restrictions including that those arriving by plane must use airlines in agreement with Riyadh.\n\nDespite the ongoing diplomatic and political rift with Qatar, Saudi Arabia has made a
